Identification.LongTitle: Criminal Proceedings Rules of the Manitoba Court of Queen’s Bench

Provision.Text: The Manitoba Court of Queen’s Bench, pursuant to subsections 482(1)a and (3)b and section 482.1c of the Criminal Coded, makes the annexed Criminal Proceedings Rules of the Manitoba Court of Queen’s Bench.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in these rules.

Definition.Text: appeal means an appeal from a decision of a summary conviction court under Part XXVII of the Code. (appel)
assignment court means the sitting of the Court when trial and pre-trial proceedings are scheduled for hearing. (audience de fixation du rôle)
Charter means the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. (Charte)
counsel means the counsel of record or counsel specifically authorized to act on behalf of the counsel of record. (avocat)
Court means the Court of Queen’s Bench of Manitoba. (Cour)
holiday includes any day that the Court office is closed. (jour férié)
judge means a judge of the Court. (juge)
pre-trial conference has the same meaning as a pre-hearing conference referred to in section 625.1 of the Code. (conférence préparatoire)
proceeding includes a trial, application, appeal or other process arising from or incidental to the prosecution of an offence under the Code. (instance)

summary conviction appeals assignment court means the sitting of the Court when summary conviction appeals are scheduled for hearing. (audience de fixation du rôle des appels d’une déclaration de culpabilité par procédure sommaire)

Section.Text: These rules are enacted under subsection 482(1) of the Code and apply to proceedings that are within the jurisdiction of the Court.

Subsection.Text: These rules are intended to provide for the just determination of every proceeding and must be construed to secure simplicity in procedure, fairness in administration and the elimination of unjustifiable expense and delay.
If matters are not provided for in these rules, the practice must be determined by analogy to them.
If an accused is self-represented, anything that these rules require or permit counsel to do must be done by the accused, except if these rules provide otherwise.

Section.Text: The interpretation sections of the Code apply to these rules, except if these rules provide otherwise.
A judge may dispense with compliance with a rule only if it is, and to the extent that it is, necessary in the interests of justice.

If an applicant has failed to comply with the rules respecting the filing of a document in support of a motion or application, the motion or application must not be heard unless the presiding judge grants leave, after taking into account all the circumstances of the case, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the applicant’s non-compliance with these rules;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any explanation advanced for failing to comply with these rules;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the apparent merits of the motion or application as reflected in any materials filed and any submissions made in the proceeding;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any notice given to the other parties about the issues raised in the motion or application and the right of those parties to have a reasonable opportunity to respond to the issues raised by the applicant; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the history of the proceedings and the need for an expeditious determination of pre-trial motions and applications and the orderly conduct of trial proceedings.

Subsection.Text: The Court may order costs, payable by counsel personally, if counsel has failed, without reasonable excuse, to comply with these rules, having regard to the factors set out in rule 2.02.
If the Court orders that counsel pay costs for non-compliance, they are payable to the Minister of Finance for Manitoba.

Section.MarginalNote: Deemed undertaking by counsel and prosecutor
Section.Text: Counsel for the accused and the prosecutor assigned to a case are each deemed to undertake to comply with all time limits that are set by a pre-trial judge, case management judge or another judge.
Unless the context requires otherwise, the computation of a time limit prescribed by these rules or imposed by a judge is to be done in the following manner:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if there is a reference to a number of clear days or “at least” a number of days between two events, both the day on which the first event happens and the day on which the second event happens are excluded;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if a period of less than seven days is prescribed, any holidays that fall during that period are excluded; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the time for the doing of an act expires on a holiday, the act may be done on the next day that is not a holiday.

Subsection.Text: The Court may, by order, extend or abridge any time limit prescribed by these rules or imposed by a judge, on any terms that it considers just.
An application for an order extending a time limit may be made before or after the expiry of the time limit.

Section.Text: Subject to rule 4.02, a proceeding must be commenced in the judicial centre nearest to the place where the cause of the proceeding arose.

Section.MarginalNote: Ease of access to judicial centre
Section.Text: Ease of access from the place where the cause of the proceeding arose to a judicial centre is to be a factor in a decision as to which centre is the nearest.
A proceeding must be heard in the judicial centre in which it is commenced unless the Court orders otherwise.
An application to change the venue of a trial from the judicial centre where the proceeding was commenced to another judicial centre is to be governed by the change of venue provisions of the Code.

Section.MarginalNote: No effect on validity of proceeding
Section.Text: The validity of a proceeding is not affected solely by a failure to comply with rule 4.01 or 4.03, but the Court may, on an application or on its own motion, transfer the proceeding to the appropriate judicial centre or make any other order that it considers just.

Subsection.Text: All documents that are required to be filed in a proceeding must be filed with the court office in the judicial centre at which the proceeding was commenced, except if they are filed in the course of a hearing.
Any document may be filed by leaving it in, or mailing it to, the court office, accompanied by any prescribed fee.
A document that is filed by mail is deemed to have been filed on the date of the court office’s filing stamp on it.
The registrar may refuse to accept a document for filing that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: does not comply with the format required by these rules;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is illegible; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is not securely bound or fastened together.

Subsection.Text: If the registrar refuses to accept a document for filing, the document must not be filed without a judge’s direction.

Section.Text: The forms prescribed in the schedule are to be used if applicable and with any variations that the circumstances require.
All documents must be printed on good quality white paper that is 216 mm wide and 279 mm long and the text must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be printed only on one side of the paper, except for books of authorities, which must be double-sided;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: other than for books of authorities, be double spaced, except for quotations, which must be single spaced; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: have margins of approximately 25 mm.

Section.Text: Every document in a proceeding must have a covering page in Form 1 of the schedule that indicates

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the title of the proceeding;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the court, the judicial centre and the court file number;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an affidavit, the deponent’s name and the date on which he or she swore or affirmed it;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the title of the document; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, email address and telephone and fax numbers of the person filing the document.

Section.MarginalNote: Covers for briefs, factums and books of authorities
Section.Text: Covers for briefs, factums and books of authorities must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the applicant’s or appellant’s brief, factum or book of authorities, be bound front and back in blue cover stock;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the respondent’s brief, factum or book of authorities, be bound front and back in beige cover stock; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the intervener’s brief, factum or book of authorities, be bound front and back in grey cover stock.

Subsection.Text: A motion or application brief must be set out in consecutively numbered paragraphs and contain the following parts:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Part 1 — an introduction or overview of the case;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Part 2 — a concise statement of the facts;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Part 3 — a list of the issues;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: Part 4 — a concise statement of the argument and the relief requested;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: Part 5 — a list of the authorities relied on; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: Schedule A, entitled “Relevant Legislative Provisions” — the text of all relevant legislation.

Subsection.Text: The brief must be signed by counsel or by the applicant or respondent if he or she is self-represented. The signature must be followed by the typed name of the person and the date.
Unless a judge directs otherwise, the brief — excluding Schedule A — must not exceed 30 pages in length.
In the case of a summary conviction appeal, the factum must be set out in consecutively numbered paragraphs and contain the following parts:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Part 1 — an introduction or overview of the case;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Part 2 — a concise statement of the facts;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Part 3 — a list of the issues;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: Part 4 — the standard of review;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: Part 5 — a concise statement of the argument and the relief requested;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: Part 6 — a list of the authorities relied on; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: Schedule A, entitled “Relevant Legislative Provisions” — the text of all relevant legislation.

Subsection.Text: Subrules 5.07(2) and (3) also apply to appeal factums.
Books of authorities must contain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an index; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subrule (4), those authorities that are relied on by the party, including the head note, if any, with the relevant portions of the authorities highlighted or sidebarred.

Subsection.Text: The authorities must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: separated by numbered tabs; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: printed on both sides of each page.

Subsection.Text: A party must not duplicate authorities that have been filed by any other party.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Case law for well-known principles of law
Subsection.Text: A party must not include in a book of authorities a case that establishes a well-known principle of law, unless there is something specific in the case that is relevant to the proceeding before the Court.

Section.Text: An order must be in Form 2 of the schedule and must indicate

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the judge who made it;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which it was made; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a recital of the particulars necessary to understand the order, including the date of the hearing, the parties who were present or represented by counsel and those who were neither present nor represented and any undertaking made by a party as a condition of the order.

Section.Text: All documents filed with the Court by the parties in connection with a resolution conference, pre-trial conference or case management conference, and any transcripts of those conferences, are confidential and are not part of the public record. They must be kept in a separate court file for the proceeding, known as a “B” file.
The prosecutor, counsel for each accused and any self-represented accused in a proceeding are entitled to have access to the contents of the “B” file that is kept for that proceeding.

Heading.TitleText: General Rules for Manner of Service

Subsection.Text: No document is required to be served personally unless the Code, these rules or an order of the Court requires personal service.
When a motion or an application is served on a person who is not a party to the proceeding, the motion or the application must be served personally.
When a document is to be served personally, the service must be made in the following manner:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if on an individual, by giving a copy of the document to the individual;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if on a corporation, by giving a copy of the document to an officer, director or agent of the corporation or to a person who appears to be in charge at the place where the corporation carries on business;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if on a judge of the Provincial Court of Manitoba or a justice of the peace, by giving a copy of the document to the court administrator in charge of the court office in the region where the adjudication was made;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if on the Attorney General of Canada, by leaving a copy of the document at the regional office of the Attorney General of Canada in Winnipeg; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: if on the Attorney General of Manitoba, by leaving a copy of the document at the office of the prosecutor in the judicial centre where the proceeding was commenced.

Subsection.Text: A person effecting personal service of a document is not required to produce the original document or have it in his or her possession.

Section.Text: Any document that is not required to be served personally may be served

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on a party who has counsel of record, by serving that counsel in the manner set out in rule 7.04; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on a party who is self-represented,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: by mailing a copy of the document in the manner set out in rule 7.05,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: by faxing a copy of the document in the manner set out in subrule 7.04(2), or

Subsection.Text: Service of a document on the counsel of a party may be made

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by giving a copy of the document to the counsel, or to another counsel or employee in the counsel’s office;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by mailing a copy of the document to the counsel’s office, in the manner set out in rule 7.05;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: by faxing a copy of the document to the counsel’s office, in the manner set out in subrule (2); or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the counsel of a party agrees, by attaching a copy of the document to an email message sent to the email address provided by the counsel.

Subsection.Text: A document that is served by fax must include a cover page that indicates

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the sender’s name, address and telephone number;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the person to be served;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the transmission;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the total number of pages faxed, including the cover page;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the fax number from which the document is transmitted; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the name and telephone number of a person to contact in the event of transmission problems.

Subsection.Text: If a document is to be served by mail under these rules, a copy of the document may be sent by regular mail or by registered mail.
Service of a document by regular mail is effective on the fifth day after the day on which the document is mailed.

Heading.TitleText: Substituted Service or Dispensing with Service

Subsection.Text: If it appears to the Court that it is impractical for any reason to effect prompt personal service of a document that is required to be served personally under these rules, the Court may make an order for substituted service or, if it is necessary in the interests of justice, may dispense with service.
In an order for substituted service, the Court must specify when service in accordance with the order is effective.

Heading.TitleText: If Document Does Not Reach Person Served

Section.Text: If a document was served in compliance with the Code, these rules or an order about service, but a person to whom it was to be served can show that the document did not come to their notice, or only came to their notice at some time later than when it was served or is deemed to have been served, the person may bring a motion

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for the setting aside of an order that was made in their absence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for an extension of time; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for an adjournment.

Section.Text: If a document has been served in a manner other than one authorized by these rules or an order, the Court may make an order validating the service if the Court is satisfied that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the document came to the notice of the person to be served; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the document was served in such a manner that it would have come to the notice of the person to be served, if it had not been for the person’s own attempts to evade service.

Subsection.Text: Service of a document may be proved

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by an affidavit of the person who served or sent the document; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by the confirmation of delivery receipt provided to the sender, if the document was served by registered mail.

Subsection.Text: A counsel’s written admission or acceptance of service is sufficient proof of service and is not required to be verified by affidavit.

Section.Text: A party who intends to refer to a transcript of evidence at the hearing of a motion or an application must file a copy of the transcript and serve it on the opposing party, unless a judge directs otherwise.

Heading.TitleText: Rule 9 — Applications for Judicial Interim Release

Section.Text: This Part applies to an application

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by an accused under subsection 520(1) or (8) or 522(1) of the Code;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by the prosecutor under subsection 521(1) or (9) of the Code;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: by an accused or the prosecutor, at any time prior to the trial, under subparagraph 523(2)(c)(ii) or subsection 523(3) of the Code; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: by an accused, if proceedings have been commenced under section 577 of the Code.

Section.MarginalNote: Notice of application and supporting materials

Subsection.Text: An application must be commenced by filing a notice of application in Form 3 of the schedule and the supporting materials required under rule 9.03 and by serving those documents personally on the accused or the prosecutor, as the case may be, at least two clear days before the date of the hearing of the application unless a judge allows a shorter period of notice.
The notice of application must indicate whether the applicant intends to call oral evidence at the hearing or rely only on affidavit evidence.
If the applicant is the accused, the notice of application must be accompanied by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the affidavit of the applicant containing the matters required under paragraphs (3)(a) to (e);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if it is practicable to do so, the affidavit of the current or prospective employer by whom it is proposed that the accused be employed if released; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if it is practicable to do so, the affidavit of any person who is proposed to serve as a surety for the accused if released, indicating his or her willingness to serve as a surety and the amount for which he or she is to be liable.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Materials for use on application — previous order
Subsection.Text: If the applicant seeks to review an order made previously, the notice of application must be accompanied by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a certificate from Manitoba’s transcription services confirming that at least three copies of the transcript of the proceedings under review and any previous review proceedings have been ordered, and that the order for the copies has been accepted; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a legible copy of any exhibits capable of reproduction that were filed in the judicial interim release hearing or in any previous review proceeding.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Affidavit of applicant who is accused
Subsection.Text: The affidavit of the applicant required by paragraph (1)(a) must indicate

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the particulars of the charge in respect of which release is sought and any other charge outstanding against the applicant, together with the date or dates scheduled for the trial or preliminary inquiry in respect of the charges;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant’s place of residence in the three years before the date of the offence charged in respect of which release is sought, as well as the place where the applicant proposes to reside if released;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant’s employment in the three years before the date of the offence charged in respect of which release is sought, and whether the applicant expects to be employed if released and, if so, where the applicant expects to be employed;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where the applicant proposes that he or she be released by the giving of an undertaking with conditions or by entering into a recognizance with sureties, deposit or conditions, if it is practicable, the terms and conditions of the order sought, including the amount of any recognizance or deposit, as well as the names of any proposed sureties and the amount for which each proposed surety is to be liable; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the particulars of the applicant’s prior record, if any.

Subsection.Text: When the applicant is in custody, the registrar may accept the applicant’s unsworn affidavit for filing if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: counsel for the applicant files a written undertaking to file a sworn affidavit at, or before, the judicial interim release hearing; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant is to appear at the judicial interim release hearing by video link and the truth of the contents of the unsworn affidavit is to be confirmed by the accused to be true at the hearing.

Subsection.Text: If the applicant is the prosecutor or if, as respondent, the prosecutor intends to rely on material other than material that is required to be filed under subrule (1) or (2), the prosecutor must file an affidavit that sets out the facts on which reliance is placed, including the matters referred to in paragraph 518(1)(c) of the Code.

Section.Text: No brief is required for the purposes of an application under this Part.
The prosecutor must file the indictment with the Court at least seven days before the day on which an accused first appears in assignment court.
The judge presiding at assignment court may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: schedule a resolution conference, if the accused has elected to be tried by a judge and jury;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: schedule a pre-trial conference, if the accused has elected to be tried by a judge alone;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: schedule a date for a sentencing hearing, if the accused indicates that he or she will be entering a guilty plea to the charge; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: refer the matter to the Chief Justice for the appointment of a case management judge in accordance with section 551.1 of the Code.

Section.Text: Rules 11.02 to 11.06 apply to a resolution conference if the accused has elected to be tried by a judge and jury.
The resolution conference judge must explore

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the possibility of settlement with the parties; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any matters that will promote a fair and efficient trial, including re-election by the accused and the appointment of a case management judge in accordance with section 551.1 of the Code.

Section.Text: Before a resolution conference is held, unless a judge directs otherwise, a pre-trial conference brief in Form 4 of the schedule must be filed and served on the opposing party by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the prosecutor;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: counsel for each accused; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any self-represented accused.

Section.MarginalNote: Application of pre-trial rules to resolution conferences
Section.Text: Rules 12.02, 12.03, 12.05 and 12.06, which apply to pre-trial conferences, also apply, with any variations that the circumstances require, to resolution conferences.

Subsection.Text: The resolution conference judge must complete a resolution conference memorandum, which must be provided to the prosecutor, counsel for each accused and any self-represented accused.

The resolution conference memorandum is not part of the public record and must be kept in the custody of the Court in the “B” file for the proceeding and be disclosed only in accordance with subrule (1).

Section.Text: At the conclusion of a resolution conference, if it appears that the matter will be proceeding to trial, the presiding judge must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: schedule a pre-trial conference; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: refer the matter to the Chief Justice for the appointment of a case management judge and provide the Chief Justice with a copy of the resolution conference memorandum.

Section.Text: Rules 12.02 to 12.10 apply to pre-trial conferences.

Subsection.Text: Unless a pre-trial conference brief has already been filed for a resolution conference or a judge directs otherwise, the prosecutor must, at least 14 days before the date scheduled for the pre-trial conference, file a completed pre-trial conference brief in Form 4 of the schedule and serve it on counsel for each accused and any self-represented accused.
The prosecutor’s pre-trial conference brief must include a brief synopsis of the allegations and the evidence to be filed by the prosecution.

At least seven days before the date scheduled for the pre-trial conference, unless a judge directs otherwise, counsel for an accused or a self-represented accused must file and serve a completed pre-trial conference brief in Form 4 of the schedule on

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the prosecutor;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: counsel for any other accused; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any self-represented accused.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Mandatory filing and service by accused
Subsection.Text: Counsel for each accused and any self-represented accused must file and serve a pre-trial conference brief even if the prosecutor has failed to file and serve a pre-trial conference brief or has otherwise failed to comply with this rule.
The pre-trial conference brief must state the party’s position on each issue and must not indicate “will advise”, “not as yet” or words of similar effect.
If a party changes any position taken and recorded in the pre-trial conference brief, the party must give written notice of the change to the other parties and the pre-trial conference judge.
Failure to comply with subrule (1) may result in a motion or application that has resulted from the change in position not being heard by the trial judge.

If, after the pre-trial conference has been completed, an accused retains new counsel, an accused who was self-represented retains counsel, or an accused who was represented by counsel is no longer represented by any counsel, the new counsel, or the self-represented accused, must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: review the pre-trial conference brief previously filed and the pre-trial conference memorandum prepared by the pre-trial conference judge; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: give written notice of any changes in position to the other parties and the pre-trial conference judge.

Subsection.Text: Despite rule 12.10, the pre-trial conference judge may direct that a further pre-trial conference be held if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the accused is no longer represented by counsel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a party has changed his or her position from the position taken in the most recent pre-trial conference brief; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a party has failed to file a trial readiness report, as required by rule 17.01.

Subsection.Text: If an accused is self-represented at a pre-trial conference,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the pre-trial conference must be held in a courtroom that is closed to the public;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the pre-trial conference must be recorded but must not be published, broadcast or transmitted in any way, except by order of the pre-trial conference judge; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a transcript of the pre-trial conference may only be requested by a party to the proceeding or by a judge.

Subsection.Text: If a transcript has been requested under paragraph (1)(c), information contained in it must not be published, broadcast or transmitted in any way except with notice to the other parties and the written approval of the pre-trial conference judge or, if he or she is not available, another judge.

Section.Text: Unless the pre-trial conference judge or another judge directs otherwise, the following persons must attend the pre-trial conference and be in a position to make commitments on behalf of the party whom each represents on issues that are reasonably anticipated to arise from the contents of the pre-trial conference briefs:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: counsel who will be representing each accused at the trial or, if an accused is self-represented, the accused; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the prosecutor.

Section.Text: The pre-trial conference judge must inquire about and discuss any matter that may promote a fair and expeditious hearing of the charges contained in the indictment, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any issues that arise from the contents of the pre-trial conference briefs;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the issues in dispute between the parties;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the possibility of making admissions of fact or other agreements about uncontested issues or the evidence of witnesses;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the simplification of any issues that remain in controversy;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the resolution of any outstanding disclosure issues;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the nature and particulars of any pre-trial motion or application, including whether evidence on the motion or application will be provided by agreed statements of facts, excerpts of transcripts of the preliminary inquiry, affidavits, “will states” or otherwise than by the testimony of witnesses;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the estimated length of pre-trial hearings and trial proceedings;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the possibility that the prosecutor may reduce the number of counts in the indictment to facilitate jury comprehension and promote a fair, just and expeditious trial;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the manner in which evidence may be presented at trial to facilitate jury comprehension; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: whether counsel are of the opinion that, for the proper administration of justice, it is necessary to have a case management judge appointed in accordance with section 551.1 of the Code.

Subsection.Text: The pre-trial conference judge must complete a pre-trial conference memorandum, which must be provided to the trial judge, the prosecutor, counsel for each accused and any self-represented accused.

The pre-trial conference memorandum is not part of the public record. It must be kept in the custody of the Court in the “B” file for the proceeding and may be disclosed only in accordance with subrule (1).

Section.Text: After completing a pre-trial conference, the judge must do at least one of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: schedule a further pre-trial conference, if the matter is not yet ready to be scheduled for trial;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: schedule any pre-trial hearings;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: set deadlines for filing documents;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: refer the matter to the Chief Justice, with a copy of the pre-trial memorandum, for the appointment of a case management judge in accordance with section 551.1 of the Code;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: schedule a sentencing hearing, if the accused indicates that he or she will be entering a guilty plea; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: schedule the trial.

Section.Text: Unless the case is to be tried with a jury or there are exceptional circumstances, there must be no more than three pre-trial conferences.
Rules 13.02 to 13.06 apply to case management conferences that are conducted under section 551.1 of the Code.

Subsection.Text: The judge who is appointed to conduct a case management conference may be the same judge who conducted the resolution conference or the pre-trial conference with respect to the matter.
The judge who is appointed to conduct the conference has the powers of a case management judge under sections 551.2 to 551.4 and 551.6 of the Code.

Section.Text: If a pre-trial conference was not held prior to the holding of a case management conference, pre-trial conference briefs must be filed and served in accordance with rules 12.02 to 12.04.
After completing a case management conference, the case management judge must schedule

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a further case management conference, if the matter is not yet ready to be scheduled for trial;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any pre-trial motions or applications; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the trial.

Subsection.Text: The case management judge must complete a case management memorandum, which must be provided to the trial judge, the prosecutor, counsel for each accused and any self-represented accused.

The case management conference memorandum is not part of the public record. It must be kept in the custody of the Court in the “B” file for the proceeding and be disclosed only in accordance with subrule (1).

If a party changes a position that has been taken and recorded in the case management memorandum, the party must give written notice of the change to the other parties and the case management conference judge.
Failure to comply with subrule (1) may result in a motion or application resulting from the change in position not being heard by the trial judge.

Section.Text: Rules 14.02 to 14.06 apply if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the Code or another Act of Parliament permits or requires that an application be made for an order or determination by a judge and there is no specific rule governing the procedure; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a party seeks a ruling before a trial as to the admissibility of evidence, other than under subsection 24(2) of the Charter.

Subsection.Text: An application must be commenced by filing a notice of motion in Form 5 of the schedule.

If the issue that is the subject of the motion is identified at a pre-trial or case management conference, the pre-trial conference judge or the case management judge must set time limits for filing and serving the notice of motion and supporting materials.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Scheduling conference to set hearing dates
Subsection.Text: If the issue that is the subject of the motion has not been identified at a pre-trial or case management conference, the party making the motion must schedule another pre-trial or case management conference to set hearing dates and time limits for filing materials.

Section.Text: Every notice of motion must state

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the place and date of hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the precise relief sought;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the grounds to be argued, including a reference to any statutory provision or rule to be relied on;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: whether the motion is to be based on oral evidence and, if not, the documentary, affidavit and other evidence to be used at the hearing of the application; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: whether any order is required to abridge or extend any time limit for filing or serving the notice of motion or supporting materials required under these rules.

Section.MarginalNote: Filing and serving motion record and supporting materials

Subsection.Text: An applicant must file a motion record and any supporting materials and serve those documents on the other parties within the time limits set by the pre-trial conference judge or the case management judge.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Filing of documents as part of record
Subsection.Text: Any documents served by a party for use on a motion may be filed as part of the party’s motion record and need not be filed separately if the motion record is filed within the time limits set by a judge under subrule (1).
The applicant’s motion record must contain, in the following order:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a table of contents describing each document;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the notice of motion;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the indictment to which the motion relates;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of all affidavits and other material to be relied on;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a list of all relevant transcripts of evidence in chronological order, but not necessarily the transcripts themselves; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of any other material in the Court file that is necessary for the hearing of the motion.

Subsection.Text: If the respondent seeks to rely on material that is not included in the applicant’s motion record, the respondent must file and serve a motion record on the other parties within the time limits set by the pre-trial conference judge or the case management judge.

Section.Text: Each party must file and serve a brief and a book of authorities on the other parties within the time limits set by the pre-trial conference judge or the case management judge.

Subsection.Text: Subject to the Code or any other applicable statute or rule of law, a person who has sworn or affirmed an affidavit may be cross-examined on the affidavit at the hearing of a motion with leave of the presiding judge.
Nothing in these rules is to be construed so as to affect the authority of the judge who is hearing a motion to receive evidence through the examination of witnesses.

Section.Text: Rules 15.02 to 15.07 apply if the constitutional validity or constitutional applicability of any enactment or common law rule is challenged or an application is made for a remedy under subsection 24(1) of the Charter.

Subsection.Text: An application under rule 15.01 must be commenced by filing a notice of motion in Form 5 of the schedule.

If the issue that is the subject of the motion is identified at a pre-trial or case management conference, the pre-trial conference judge or the case management judge must set time limits for filing and serving the notice of motion and supporting materials.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Scheduling conference to set hearing dates
Subsection.Text: If the issue that is the subject of the motion has not been identified at a pre-trial or case management conference, the party making the motion must schedule another pre-trial or case management conference to set hearing dates and time limits for filing materials.

Section.Text: The notice of motion must state the matters set out in rule 14.03 and state whether the applicant seeks to have the motion heard in advance of the trial.

A responding party to the motion may file a notice of motion requesting a determination as to whether the matter can be heard in advance of the trial or should be deferred until a later stage in the trial.

Section.MarginalNote: Filing and serving affidavit and other documents
Section.Text: An applicant must file and serve on all other interested parties any affidavit or documentary evidence on which the applicant intends to rely within the time limits set by the pre-trial conference judge or the case management judge.

Section.MarginalNote: Applicant’s brief and book of authorities

Subsection.Text: The applicant must file a brief and a book of authorities and serve those documents within the time limits set by the pre-trial conference judge or the case management judge.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Respondent’s brief and book of authorities
Subsection.Text: The respondent must file a brief and a book of authorities and serve those documents within the time limits set by the pre-trial conference judge or the case management judge.
A person may seek leave to intervene in an application if the constitutional validity or applicability of a law is challenged.
The judge presiding over the proceeding or, if a judge has not yet been assigned, another judge of the Court may grant leave to intervene if he or she is satisfied that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person has an interest in the issue before the Court;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person will make submissions that are different than those of the other parties; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the intervention will not unduly delay or prejudice the determination of the rights of the parties.

Subsection.Text: An order granting leave to intervene may be granted on any terms that the judge determines are just.

Heading.TitleText: Rule 16 — Applications to Exclude Evidence Under the Charter

Section.Text: Rules 16.02 to 16.05 apply if a party seeks to exclude evidence under subsection 24(2) of the Charter.
An application to exclude evidence must be commenced by filing a notice of motion in Form 5 of the schedule that must state

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the place and date of hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a detailed description of the evidence the applicant seeks to exclude in the proceedings;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of the basis and grounds on which the evidence is said to be inadmissible; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a summary of the evidence or other material on which the applicant relies and a statement of the manner in which the applicant proposes to present the evidence.

Subsection.Text: If the issue that is the subject of the motion is identified at a pre-trial conference or case management conference, the pre-trial judge or the case management judge must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: determine if motion briefs will be required; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: set hearing dates and time limits for filing and serving the notice of motion, unless it has already been filed and served, and for filing and serving supporting materials.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Scheduling conference to set hearing dates
Subsection.Text: If the issue that is the subject of the motion has not been identified at a pre-trial or case management conference, the party making the motion must schedule another pre-trial or case management conference to set hearing dates and time limits for filing materials.
If the application is not based on oral evidence, an applicant must file and serve a motion record that includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the indictment to which the application relates;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the affidavits and other documentary evidence relied on to support the application; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any other materials that may reasonably assist the judge in identifying and determining the admissibility issues that are being raised.

Subsection.Text: If the respondent seeks to rely on material that is not included in the applicant’s motion record, the respondent must file and serve a motion record that contains those other materials on which the respondent proposes to rely, within the time limits set by the pre-trial conference judge or the case management judge.

Section.Text: The prosecutor, counsel for each accused and any self-represented accused must file a trial readiness report in Form 6 of the schedule and serve it on the other parties at least 14 days before the trial date, or within the time that the pre-trial conference judge or case management judge directs.
A further pre-trial conference or court attendance may be directed by a judge if counsel or a self-represented accused

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has changed their position on an issue from what was indicated at the most recent pre-trial conference or case management conference;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has not complied with a filing requirement that is set out in these rules or directed by the pre-trial conference judge or case management judge; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: has not filed a trial readiness report in Form 6 of the schedule.

Subsection.Text: If the prosecutor advises the Court, in accordance with section 752.01 of the Code, that the prosecutor intends to apply to have an offender declared a dangerous offender or a long-term offender, the Court must set a date for a pre-hearing conference before the Chief Justice or his or her designate within 60 days after the day on which the offender is convicted.
The purpose of the conference is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to discuss the procedure to be followed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to determine what matters will be contentious; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: to schedule the hearing of the application.

Section.Text: At least 14 days before the date of the pre-hearing conference, the prosecutor must file a pre-hearing conference report for a dangerous or long-term offender application in Form 7 of the schedule and serve it on the offender.

At least seven days before the date of the pre-hearing conference, the offender must file a pre-hearing conference report for a dangerous or long-term offender application in Form 7 of the schedule and serve it on the prosecutor.

This Part applies to applications by way of certiorari, habeas corpus, mandamus, procedendo and prohibition, including applications to quash a subpoena, warrant, conviction, inquiry or other order or determination and applications for discharge of a person in custody.
The application must be commenced by filing a notice of application in Form 3 of the schedule, which must state the subpoena, warrant or other order or determination to which the application relates.
If the subject of the application is the review of an order, the applicant must file and serve the notice of application within 30 days after the day on which the order was made.
The notice of application and any supporting materials must be served

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the application includes an application for prohibition, by personal service on the Provincial Court of Manitoba judge, the justice of the peace or other person whose order is the subject of the application;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the applicant is Her Majesty the Queen, if the respondent is a self-represented accused, by personal service on the accused or, if the respondent is an accused represented by counsel, by service on that counsel; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where the applicant is the accused, by personal service on the prosecutor.

Heading.TitleText: Required Documents, Brief and Book of Authorities

Subsection.Text: The notice of application must be accompanied by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the subpoena, warrant, conviction or other order or determination that is the subject of the application;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the indictment or information that contains the charge to which the application relates;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if there is no record or an incomplete record of the proceedings giving rise to the issuance of the subpoena, warrant, conviction or other order or determination that is the subject of the application, an affidavit of, or on behalf of, the applicant that includes the matters set out in subrule (2);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a transcript of the proceedings giving rise to the issuance of the subpoena, warrant, conviction or other order or determination that is the subject of the application, including the reasons, if any, given by the Provincial Court of Manitoba judge or justice of the peace who issued the order; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of any other material filed in the proceeding that gave rise to the application and that is necessary for the hearing and determination of the application.

Subsection.Text: The affidavit referred to in paragraph (1)(c) must include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the status of the person making the affidavit and the basis of his or her knowledge of the matters deposed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of the particulars of the charge to which the application relates, together with a date or dates scheduled for trial or preliminary inquiry in respect of that charge;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of all facts that are material to a just determination of the application that are not disclosed in any other materials filed in support of the application; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the applicant seeks habeas corpus to obtain release from custody, a statement that the applicant is not required to be detained in custody in respect of any other matter.

Section.MarginalNote: Applicant’s brief and book of authorities
Section.Text: Unless a judge directs otherwise, the applicant must file and serve a brief and book of authorities at least 30 days before the date of the hearing of the application.

Section.MarginalNote: Respondent’s brief and book of authorities
Section.Text: Unless a judge directs otherwise, the respondent must file and serve a brief and book of authorities at least 14 days before the date of the hearing of the application.

Heading.Label: PART 7
Heading.TitleText: Summary Conviction Appeals and Stays Pending Appeal

Subsection.Text: A prosecutor who wishes to commence an appeal from an acquittal, order or sentence must file a notice of appeal in Form 8 of the schedule no later than 30 days after the day on which the acquittal, order or sentence under appeal is pronounced.

A defendant who wishes to commence an appeal from a conviction or sentence must file a notice of appeal in Form 8 of the schedule no later than 30 days after the day on which the sentence is pronounced.

Section.Text: The appellant must state their address for service on the notice of appeal, including their telephone number, fax number and email address, if any.
The appellant must notify the Court in writing of any change to the contact information in the notice of appeal.
The appellant must serve the notice of appeal personally on the respondent no later than 30 days after the date on which it is filed.

Subsection.Text: A notice of appeal must be accompanied by a certificate from Manitoba’s transcription services confirming that at least three copies of the transcript of the proceedings have been ordered and that the order has been accepted.
Subrule (1) does not apply if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the appellant has applied under rule 20.16 for a trial de novo; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the appeal is made under section 830 of the Code and based on a statement of agreed facts.

Section.Text: If an appeal is only against the sentence, the appellant is not required to provide a transcript of the proceedings that does not pertain to the sentence.
Once the transcript of the proceedings that is the subject of the appeal has been filed with the Court,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the appeal must be placed on the summary conviction appeal assignment court list; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the prosecutor must give the defendant notice of the court date by registered mail.

Section.Text: The judge presiding at the summary conviction appeal assignment court must set time limits for filing and serving appeal books, factums and books of authorities.
If the appellant fails to appear personally or by counsel in the summary conviction appeal assignment court, the court may dismiss the appeal.

Section.MarginalNote: Filing of appeal book by prosecutor
Section.Text: The prosecutor is required to file an appeal book regardless of whether the prosecutor is the appellant or the respondent.
An appeal book must contain, in the following order,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a table of contents;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the information;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the notice of appeal;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: all documentary exhibits relevant to the appeal;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the reasons for the decision, whether or not they are contained in the transcript of evidence;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: if there is an appeal as to the sentence, pre-sentence reports and other exhibits that were filed at the sentencing hearing; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: any other materials that may be necessary to enable the Court to adjudicate the issues on appeal.

Section.Text: The prosecutor must have access, for the purpose of preparing an appeal book, to the court file and all documents and exhibits that are delivered to the registrar by the trial court.
A defendant may file a supplementary appeal book that contains materials relevant to the appeal that are omitted from the appeal book filed by the prosecutor.

Subsection.Text: The appellant and the respondent are each required to file a factum and book of authorities, unless the judge presiding at the summary conviction appeal assignment court otherwise directs.
Rule 5.08 applies to the factum.

Section.Text: An appellant may abandon an appeal by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: signing and filing a notice of abandonment in Form 9 of the schedule; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: serving the notice on the respondent.

Subsection.Text: An appellant who seeks a trial de novo under subsection 822(4) of the Code must file and serve a notice of motion at the time of filing and serving the notice of appeal.
The notice of motion must set out the grounds on which the trial de novo is sought.
The notice of motion must be placed on the summary conviction appeal assignment court list.
If a trial de novo is sought, the judge presiding at the summary conviction appeal assignment court may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: determine if further materials should be filed by the parties; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if necessary, set a date for the hearing of the motion.

Section.Text: An appeal is deemed to be ready to be heard if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any application under subsection 822(4) of the Code has been determined;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Court has received the appeal book and a transcript of the evidence, if required; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the appellant and the respondent have each filed a factum and book of authorities and served them on the other party, unless a judge has dispensed with the filing of those documents.

Section.Text: A judge may dismiss an appeal if an appellant who is required to file a factum or book of authorities has not done so within the time limit set by the judge presiding at the summary conviction appeal assignment court and has not sought an extension of time to file those documents.

If a respondent who is required to file a factum or book of authorities has not done so within the time limit set by the judge presiding at the summary conviction appeal assignment court and has not sought an extension of time to file those documents,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a judge may set the matter for hearing; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the respondent is not allowed to file a factum or book of authorities after the matter is set for hearing without leave of the Court.

Section.Text: If the appellant fails to appear personally or by counsel on the date fixed for hearing the appeal, the Court may summarily dismiss the appeal.
If a respondent fails to appear personally or by counsel on the date of the hearing of the appeal, the Court may proceed with the appeal in the absence of the respondent.
Rules 21.02 to 21.05 apply to applications for an order

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: under section 261 of the Code for a stay of an order of prohibition under section 259 of the Code; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: under subsection 683(5) of the Code to suspend an order of the trial court.

Section.Text: An application referred to in rule 21.01 must be made by filing a notice of motion in Form 5 of the schedule that sets out the relief requested, accompanied by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the information that contains the charge in respect of the offence of which the applicant was convicted;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the notice of appeal;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an affidavit of the applicant that includes the matters set out in subrule 21.03(1) or (2), as the case may be; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of any other material in the court file that is necessary for the hearing and determination of the application.

Subsection.Text: If the application is made under paragraph 21.01(a), the affidavit of the applicant must contain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the particulars of the offence of which the applicant was convicted, including reference to the results of any analysis of the applicant’s bodily substances to determine the presence of alcohol or drugs and whether the offence involved property damage, bodily harm or death;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the particulars of the applicant’s driving record, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the particulars of the applicant’s criminal record, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a statement as to whether the applicant is addicted to the use of alcohol or drugs and, if so, what steps, if any, the applicant has undertaken or proposes to undertake for the treatment of that addiction pending the determination of the appeal; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the particulars of any unnecessary hardship that would be caused to the applicant if the stay or suspension were not ordered.

Subsection.Text: If the application is made under paragraph 21.01(b), the affidavit of the applicant must state

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: why there is merit to the appeal; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the particulars of any unnecessary hardship that would be caused to the applicant if the stay or suspension were not ordered.

Section.Text: The applicant must serve the notice of motion and supporting materials on the prosecutor personally at least two clear days before the date fixed for the hearing of the application.

Subsection.Text: The prosecutor may consent, in writing, to the order sought by the applicant on the terms included in a draft order.
If a judge is satisfied that the relief sought by the applicant should be granted, the judge may grant the order on the terms sought, without the attendance of counsel.

Section.Text: [Repeal]
These rules come into force on October 1, 2016.

Provision.Text: (If the document is an affidavit, indicate the name of the deponent and the date sworn.)

ON READING the Notice of Motion (or Application) and the evidence filed by the parties (add, if applicable, and on hearing the oral evidence presented by the parties) and on hearing the submissions of counsel for (identify parties) (add, if applicable, and the submissions of (identify party appearing on his or her own behalf)) (add, if applicable, and, after having observed the non-appearance of or no one appearing for (identify party), although properly served as appears from (indicate proof of service)):

(name and address of the respondent or the respondent’s counsel)

Provision.Text: This Form must be filed by the assigned prosecutor and by counsel for each accused person or, if self-represented, the accused, before the first pre-trial conference or the resolution conference, whichever occurs earlier, unless otherwise ordered.
Each party must provide their position on each issue and not indicate they “will advise” or “not as yet”, etc.

The prosecutor must file this Form and serve it on defence counsel or, if self-represented, the accused, at least 14 days before the pre-trial conference or resolution conference. Counsel or the self-represented accused must file and serve their brief on the prosecutor at least seven days before the pre-trial conference or the resolution conference, regardless of whether the Crown has filed the Form. In cases where the Crown has not filed the Form or has filed it late, defence counsel or the self-represented accused should complete the Form to the extent possible.

If any party changes the position taken on this Form, they must provide written notice to the other party and to the pre-trial judge of the change in position. If a party has not indicated that an application or motion will be brought, the presumption is that it will not be heard. The failure to notify the other side and the Court of any application not indicated on this Form will be a factor considered by the trial judge in determining whether the new position has prejudiced the other party and whether the application may proceed.

The prosecutor’s copy of the brief must be accompanied by a brief synopsis of the allegations and the theory of the Crown’s case. If the prosecutor is arguing that the accused is liable to an offence as a party, the section of the Code that is being relied on by the prosecutor must be indicated.

ScheduleFormHeading.Label: FORM 7
ScheduleFormHeading.TitleText: Pre-Hearing Conference Report for Dangerous or Long-Term Offender Application

Provision.Text: This Form must be completed in full in all cases and be signed by the assigned prosecutor or a prosecutor authorized to bind the Crown, and by counsel for the offender or, if self-represented, the offender, before the first judicial pre-hearing conference, unless otherwise ordered or unless the offender will be consenting to the application.
Each party is encouraged to discuss the issues to be addressed at the pre-hearing conference in advance of the conference.
The prosecutor must provide their position on each issue and not indicate they “will advise” or “not as yet”, etc.

The prosecutor must file this Form and serve it on defence counsel or, if self-represented, the offender, at least 14 days before the pre-trial conference. Defence counsel or the self-represented offender must file and serve their report on the prosecutor at least seven days before the pre-trial conference, regardless of whether the Crown has filed the Form. In cases where the Crown has not filed the Form or has filed it late, counsel or the self-represented offender should complete the Form to the extent possible.
If any party changes the position taken on this Form, they must provide written notice to the other party and to the Court of the change in position.
